p: Comparison of the large-scale indices (ENSO index and the LETG-SA) from the simulations ( Fig. 4a, brown and green bars, respectively) with the corresponding observed values ( Fig. 4a, middle panel) shows that while many (16) of the CMIP3 simulations reproduce observed negative CC ( Fig. 3a, top panel) at 99% significant level, only a few (10) CMIP5 simulations show this observed characteristic ( Fig. 4a, bottom panel). In particular, the CMIP3 ensemble shows a negative ENSO-CIM index at more than 99% significance level; for the CMIP5 ensemble this significance is ~95% ( Fig. 4a, thick brown bars). With respect to LETG-SA, the CMIP3 ensemble produces a positive CC as observed, but with low significance; for CMIP5 ensemble, this CC is zero ( Fig. 4a, thick green bars). Further, only CMIP3 ensemble shows LETG-SA index of the same sign and significance as that of the observed ( Fig. 4a). Thus the CMIP5 simulations have in general poorer quality than the CMIP3 simulations in reproducing the observed association between large-scale processes and CIM. Similar conclusions also hold for distribution of simulations for the regional process ( Fig. 4b). In terms of the IOD index, eight of the CMIP3 models simulate values similar to the observed and the negative trend in the seasonal rainfall; five CMIP5 simulations satisfy these twin criteria ( Table S2 and S3).
